stories.text:
Roam Research is a popular note-taking app. It's hard to say whether it's the most popular in a competitive, but it's got plenty of loyal supporters as shown by the number of people that suscribed to the 5-year-plan for 500 USD.

Recently, their lead engineer left for a YC competitor: Athens Research [1].

Is this as indicting as it looks? Or is it common? This engineer was in Roam for less than a year, so I don't think his shares were vested, so this is at least a signal that he thinks the shares in Roam are going to be worth less than shares in Athens (assuming equal participation.)

I think this is an important question for prospective users, as they're making long term investments not only money-wise but also because of data lock-in.

[1] https://twitter.com/AthensResearch/status/1414254253124866052
stories.title: Ask HN: What does it mean if lead engineer moves to competition?
This Website is hosted on an Casio fx-9750GII Calculator

stories.text:
I've been an avid follower of YC for a while, looking for cool startups. But man, some of this stuff that the organization is doing is BS.

1. They're straight up just funding projects that are direct copies of trending projects. I've seen some projects within YC that have not only taken the UI another project with the same concept but have even taken some of the copy. Where's the innovation in that?

2. If someone has already been to YC less than a year ago, why the heck do they get prioritized over others that haven't even gotten the chance at the experience yet? It's absurd, I thought the whole point of this organization was to democratize innovation.

There are a bunch of other flaws that many of you can point out. But it honestly seems like YC isn't focused on quality innovation. It just seems like they're funding projects chasing the latest trend and backing founders within that inner SV circle. what are your thoughts?
stories.title: Ask HN: Is Y Combinator is a cheap hack rn?
